name: Dawid Kasprowicz
title: Dr. phil.
cv: Dr. Dawid Kasprowicz is a research assistant at the Chair for Theory of Science and Technology. From 2005 to 2012 he studied media studies and philosophy at Ruhr University Bochum and at the Université du Littoral Côte d’Opale in Dunkerque, France. He graduated with a Master’s thesis on Bernard Stiegler’s concept of psychopower. From 2013 to 2016, he was a PhD student at the "Media Cultures of Computer Simulation" Institute for Advanced Study in Lüneburg; afterwards he was a research assistant at the chair for philosophy of digital media in Witten-Herdecke until spring 2018. He was awarded a doctorate by Leuphana University Lüneburg in April 2018. In his PhD thesis he develops a history of knowledge based on the concept of immersion. His main research fields include: Theory and history of embodiment, the concept of models and simulations in robotics, and theory of science with a focus on computational sciences.
field: Philosophy and Media Studies of Computational Sciences/Head of CSS-Lab
researchInterests: Theory and history of embodiment; epistemology of human-robot collaborations; phenomenology; philosophy of digital media.

projects.name: How to Meet Humans: Modeling and Media in Man-Robot-Collaborations
projects.description:
Since the advent of marketing buzzwords like “industry 4.0”, the image of collaborative robots that work with their human partners appeared frequently in the media. Wether with a humanoid partner or with an attentive robotic arm in the manufacturing process, collaborative labour with these new agents not only gains the attention from fairgoers. Thus, collaboration with robotic agents challenges the knowledge of engineering sciences but it also reaches deep into domains of humanities, ethics and law. Consequently, the question would not be anymore how to design robots in a human-friendly way, but rather, how the human can be adapted as a part of the robots environment?.

The project examines this question of an adaptation of man by the robot. It argues that the phenomenon of man-robot collaborations constitutes not only a special discipline in the engineering sciences but it also necessitates a new anthropology. This anthropology no longer revolves around human beings but their virtualizations as avatars or the significant data-clusters – e.g., as visualized paths of possible movements or as digital man models. This constitutes a new form of human factors, one that can’t be reduced to mere datafication of the body, since the knowledge in human-robot-collaborations extends far beyond disciplines like ergonomics and into health care systems or education. Thus, these new human factors of man-robot collaborations entail a huge knowledge transfer from the humanities into the engineering sciences and backwards.

My analysis of this knowledge transfer focusses on two methodical steps: The first is an analysis of the formalizations of body movements and their possible intentions. Here, engineers use several diverse types of models for man-robot collaborations, depending on whether a biomechanical process of the arm has to be modelled or a whole-body model has to be animated, so that the robot can 'train' to read human body postures.

The second methodical step focuses on the media involved in the encounter between man and robot. Today, virtualizations of humans are based on diverse media like tactile sensors, motion-capture techniques, 3-D graphic animation of digital human models, and machine learning methods from computer vision, which use neural networks trained with images from multiple data banks of body postures. Neither virtual movements nor avatars serve as mere representations, but they are used to enable predictions of body-space relations that react to the way human collaborators move. These predictions will become decessive factors for security standards in human-robot-interactions but also for the general imaginations of how man should socialize with her or his robotic partners. Hence, the new anthropology of human-robot-collaborations turns out as the first written anthropology for machines that have to adapt to the human as an element of their environment. The project wants to examine the transfer from the tangible body and its flesh to the data-clusters representing the human that a robot has to adapt to. This entails philosophical and media theoretical questions like: how to design man as the environment of robots? How to set standards that generate trust in human users? Instead of formulating new definitions of the human faced with robotic agents, the project wants to describe how this new anthropological episteme is set up - for the engineers, the human partners, the machines as well as the materialized robots.
